title: greta thunberg apologises world leaders against wall climate change
story: The teenage climate activist made the comment in a speech on Friday, but later said she wasnt encouraging violence and that in her native Swedish, it means to hold someone to account.The -year-old shot to prominence in August  after she began protesting outside the Swedish parliament calling for more urgent action on climate change.The demonstrations sparked a global youth movement, and Thunberg now speaks at summits and rallies around the world.Addressing a crowd of young activists in the Italian city of Turin, Thunberg said world leaders were neglecting the need to take action on climate change.“We have to make sure that they cannot do that,” she said.“We will make sure they, that we put them against the wall, and that they will have to do their job and to protect our futures.”In English, the phrase to put someone against the wall is used to refer to an execution by firing squad.Tweeting on Saturday, Thunberg wrote: Yesterday I said we must hold our leaders accountable and unfortunately said put them against the wall.That’s Swenglish: att ställa någon mot väggenmeans to hold someone accountable.That’s what happens when you improvise speeches in a second language.But of course I apologiseanyone misunderstood this.I can not enough express the fact that I - as well as the entire school strike movement- are against any possible form of violence.It goes without saying but I say it anyway.Thunberg was this week named as Time magazines Person of the Year, an annual title given to person or group that has done most to influence the events of the year.Previous winners have included Mark Zuckerberg, Winston Churchill, and  US presidents.Time editor Edward Fnthal said Thunberg had won the award for sounding the alarm about humanity’s predatory relationship with the only home we have.Responding to the announcement, President Trump wrote on twitter: So ridiculous.Greta must work on her Anger Management problem, then go to a good old fashioned movie with a friend! Chill Greta, Chill!Thunberg subsequently changed her twitter bio to read: A teenager working on her anger management problem.Currently chilling and watching a good old fashioned movie with a friend.

title: jeremy corbyn labour leader end march
story: General Secretary Jennie Formby confirmed the partys leadership contest will not even begin until the New Year.It comes as the far-left boss refused to apologise for Labours worst election result since  and astonishingly claimed his party had won the argument with its defeated manesto.In an e-mail to colleagues, Formby wrote: Jeremy has asked that the NECstart the process swtly so a new leader may be elected by the end of March.It means Corbyn will continue to appear at Prime Ministers Questions opposite Boris Johnson and lead the party as Britain leaves the EU by the end of January.The Conservatives broke down the Red Wall in the General Election - winning seats that had been held by Labour for more than  years.In a letter, Corbyn admitted the party needed to earn their trust back after their once staunch supporters were left alienated.However, he also claimed that Labour won the argument but just failed to convert it into a majority.And while previously refusing to take any blame for the resounding defeat, Corbyn - who clung to his Islington seat - said he would make no bones over the loss.In the Sunday Mirror, he wrote: I’m sorry that we came up short and I take my responsibility for it.We will learn the lessons of this defeat, above all by listening to lelong Labour voters who we’ve lost in working class communities. This party exists to represent them. We will earn their trust back.The petulant party leader had announced hell step down after leading Labour to its most humiliating election defeat since  - but refused to say when he would do so.He wrote in the Observer: I am proud that on austerity, on corporate power, on inequality and on the climate emergency we have won the arguments and rewritten the terms of political debate.But I regret that we did not succeed in converting that into a parliamentary majority for change.There is no doubt that our policies are popular, from public ownership of rail and key utilities to a massive house-building programme and a pay rise for millions.MPs and former ministers have been lining up to demand the hard-left leaders resignation after Boris Johnsons epic victory.But Labour big beasts tore into his woeful leadership and even his close ally, union baron Len McCluskey, stuck the boot in yesterday.An Opinium poll of , adults found  per cent said Mr Corbyn’s leadership was the reason they did not vote Labour.Sir Keir Starmer is now the favourite to take over as Labour boss - but Jess Phillips threw her hat in and Emily Thornberry gave a speech hinting shell go for it too. David Lammy also broke cover to suggest he will throw his hat into the ring to succeed Mr Corbyn.Monday - Mini re-shuffle to replace culture secretary, Nicky Morgan, and Welsh secretary, Alun CairnsTuesday - MPs are sworn in at the House of CommonsThursday - Boris Johnson will unveil the Queens Speech, outlining the new governments legislative programme for the coming yearFriday - Withdrawal bill brought back,the Speaker allows itJanuary  - MPs debate the withdrawal bill this weekJanuary  - Parliament needs to have passed the withdrawal bill by this date so that the agreement can be ratied by the European Parliament at its plenary session in StrasbourgJanuary , pm - Britain to leave the EUAs Labours civil war waged on, his former top aide Karie Murphy was accused of trying to throw him under the bus.The Mail on Sunday claimed the aide had formed a pact with Len McCluskey to highlight Corbyn as the reason for Labours defeat, rather than the partys policies.A source said: Karie is now dropping Jeremy like a stone. The Left can’t possibly admit their entire project was wrong so they must dump the fiasco on to Corbyn himself.The joke is, like the good Marxist he is, Jeremy will probably just quietly accept it for the sake of the collectivethat means his hard-Left dream lives on.McCluskey yesterday blasted the incontinent mess that led to the election loss.Since the defeat, Corbyns right hand man John McDonnell said he would quit as Shadow Chancellor.Meanwhile, Boris Johnson vowed he would help give Britain back its mojo so the country could stand tall.The Prime Minister secured a sweeping -seat majority on Thursday - meaning the UK is now on track to leave the EU in less than two months.And on Saturday, Mr Johnson promised to deliver his slogan to get Brexit done - and also pledged better infrastructure, better education and fantastic modern technology.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rookie driver passes his test just 14 hours after turning 17 thanks to help from driving instructor dad
story: Hot-shot Charlie Barrs became the first youngster in a decade to achieve the impressive feat - thanks to help from his driving instructor dad.Proud Steve Barrs gave his lad  to  hours practice on roads around a private aerodrome so the youngster could start learning at .It meant keen Charlie was able to take his theory test at am ON his birthday.He then jumped into a test cancellation slot three hours later the same day, sailing through the pm practical exam with flying colours.Steve, of Northampton, said: “I am unbelievably proud of Charlie and what he’s done.“It’s been in the pipeline for a long time and I’ve been telling people for years that this was the plan.“He had a really good test but I’m planning on continuing to be in the car alongside him for a while longer to make sure I can help him whilst he is getting used to le on the roads.”Charlie drove in his dad’s white Citroen C and passed his test in his hometown with just four ‘minor’ driver faults.Steve said it was a ‘military operation’ ensuring Charlie was able to do his theory and practical test on the same day.Normally drivers cannot book their practical test until after they have passed their theory test, meaning it’s very unlikely that people take the two elements on the same day.But forward-thinking Steve booked a test for another learner - which he then cancelled once Charlie passed his theory exam - before instantly re-booking his son into the vacant slot.Charlie even went out for a midnight practice drive as a learner with his dad as soon as he turned  and did a couple more hours in the morning on his provisional licence before his tests.Dad-of-three Steve, married to Phillippa, , added: “Charlie was so well drilled. He knew all the areas of the town and what to watch out for.”Charlie’s achievement echoed that of Huddersfield teen Daniel Lloyd who passed his test on his th birthday back in .The talented kart racer had just  minutes tuition ahead of his exam.His efforts trumped six-time F world champion Lewis Hamilton who is reported to have taken six hours of lessons before he passed his driving test. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: political drama of decade pictured
story: Dramatic changes to the UKs political landscape began in , when the Conservative Party gained power for the first time since  in coalition with the Liberal Democrats.Earlier in the campaign Gordon Brown suffered a now infamous campaign gaffe after a microphone picked up the PM calling Rochdale voter Gillian Duffy a bigoted woman after she spoke to him about immigration in her community.In , we saw Scotland vote to remain in the UK after following an independence referendum which saw the future of the Union thrown into doubt.David Cameron ed to Number  as the head of a majority government the following year.His election delivered crushing blows to Labours Ed Miliband and Liberal Democrat Nick Clegg, who both went on to quit as party leaders.But a decade of political drama was just getting start as Cameron called an in-out referendum on Britains membership of the European Union.Labour MP Jo Cox was murdered in her Batley and Spen constituency during the referendum campaign in a tragedy which shocked the country.Britain elected to leave on June ,  with  per cent of voters backing the Out campaign.David Cameron quit as Prime Minister and Theresa May was elected as his successor following a Conservative leadership campaign.But her reign was thrown into chaos after she lost her majority in  following the decision to call a snap general election.She was unable to pass Brexit legislation through the House of Commons and eventually stepped down earlier this year.Boris Johnson won the battle to replace her as party leader and called another general election - campaigning to finally Get Brexit Done.He took the public to the polls for the first December general election in nearly a century and crushed Jeremy Corbyns Labour with a landslide majority.The election was a number of Labour heartland seats in the North, the Midlands and Wales turn Conservative for the first time.As we move into the s, Boris will be looking to secure Brexit within its first month and potentially move the Tories towards a fth successive term in government.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn doesnt get this country
story: He isn’t. So instead he’s issued an inadequate non-apology, claiming responsibility for his “share” of the defeat.His share ! His disastrous leadership was cited as the most popular reason for not voting Labour, followed by HIS nonsensical Brexit policy, then HIS barmy plans for the economy.He and his crackpot advisers are entirely to blame for Labour’s worst electoral performance in  years.Sadly for millions of decent Labour voters, that’s not how Corbynistas see it.As Emily Thornberry has apparently made clear, in their eyes the electorate was too uneducated and bigoted to grasp the wonders of “real change”.Well, we’ve got news for the Marxist clowns.It doesn’t take a fancy degree from a top university to know an IRA-supporting, Britain-hating anti-Semite when you see one.Or to understand that a politician who promises endless freebies is clueless about economics.Corbyn and his comrades have proved that they simply don’t get this country.They must quietly slip into obscurity.THE SUN is delighted that Boris Johnson plans to decriminalise non-payment of the BBC licence fee.When we all depended on the Beeb for entertainment, forcing viewers to cough up was just about defensible.But in , when many Brits are getting their dramas from Netflix and their sport from Sky, it emphatically is not.It’s downright shocking that good citizens from poor households are getting criminal records for such a trivial non-offence. And ludicrous that courts are wasting precious time prosecuting them.The pompous and patronising BBC is losing relevance by the day.A system that locks up those who don’t pump their hard-earned cash into its bloated coffers is clearly broken.BORIS Johnson has hit the nail on the head: rotten Whitehall is ripe for reform.In almost any other line of work,you do a bad job, you’re out on your ear.But because it’s practically impossible to sack civil servants, hundreds of sub-par paper-pushers are retiring with a £,-a-year pension — an eye-popping  per cent higher than the national average.The four core values of the civil service are honesty, impartiality, integrity and objectivity — all noble principles that have been unceremoniously cast aside by the scaremongering Remoaners currently roaming Whitehall.The Prime Minister’s bold plan to give them the chop is an excellent sign that this Government means business. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince george princess charlotte christmas day church
story: George, six, and Charlotte, four, will walk with their parents William and Kate to church on Christmas Day.It will be the first time the Cambridges will do the famous walk from Sandringham House, where the Queen hosts Christmas, to St Mary Magdalene Church with the rest of the family.A royal source said: “It will be so sweet. George and Charlotte will make their Christmas debut, as long as they’re both on good form on the day.“It’s the picture all royal fans want to see. The royals walking to church on Christmas Day is a rite of passage and so William and Kate didn’t want to expose their children too early, but they feel they’re old enough now.“After all the negative focus on Prince Andrew, these pictures will also emphasise the positive future of the Royal Family.“Ultimately it’s the Queen who decides who does what on Christmas Day as it is a formal engagement.“So perhaps she is conscious that this is a positive way in which to change the narrative.”The Sun understands that Prince Andrew will also go to church along with the rest of the family but it’s likely he’ll go in the car with the Queen instead of walking from the ‘Big House’.William and Kate will leave Louis at home with Kate‘s parents while they go to church as at  months he’s still too young.William made his first Christmas appearance in  aged five at St George’s Chapel in Windsor, looking very at ease as he waved at photographers.Harry joined his brother the following year aged four for the Royal Family’s Christmas Day service at Sandringham.As the Sun first revealed, Harry and Meghan are not joining the rest of the royals this year, instead spending Christmas with Meghan’s mum Doria Ragland. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tory win extra wine mps
story: Tory bosses say they have had to order  extra bottles of wine because the landslide win gave the PM more members than expected.Boris will use Thursday’s Queen’s Speech to unveil a series of measures designed to repay the working-class voters who deserted Labour in their droves to back him.Details came as behind-the-scenes photos emerged of his celebrations when Thursday night’s exit poll pointed to his emphatic victory.It will include radical new laws for housing tenants to finally bring an end to “no-fault evictions”, an effective ban on rail strikes and an end to early prison release for terrorists.On Friday, the PM will take the first fresh step towards his priority of getting Brexit done by holding the historic Commons vote on his EU deal with Brussels.But last night, Tory sources began to reveal the contents of Thursday’s speech, which sets out the Government’s legislative agenda for the next  months.More than million renters will be protected by the move to repeal section  of the Housing Act , which allows landlords to take back properties without needing a reason.The PM will tell new MPs to use the next five years to relentlessly make his election pledges come true to reward the party’s new supporters in the former Labour heartlands of the North.Control of Britains borders and improvements to the NHS will be at the centre of a shake-up designed to cement Conservative rule throughout the s.The Queen’s Speech will also include a law to stop councils and other public bodies boycotting products from other countries such as Israel.Mr Johnson will also appoint at least two new members to his Cabinet.Summing up what the PM’s message will be to his new MPs today, a No source said last night: “The seismic events on Thursday ed Conservative MPs in Bolsover, in Blythe and in Bishop Auckland to name but a few.This election and the new generation of MPs that have resulted from Labour towns turning blue will help change our politics for the better.“The PM has been clear we have a responsibility to deliver a better future for our country and that we must repay the publics trust by getting Brexit done.”He also said they would be “building a better Britain for everyone in this country, regardless of how they voted.He added: “Our job is to serve the people of this country, and the people’s government will deliver on the people’s priorities.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: flu cases soar parents vaccinate kids
story: Doctors said jabs are the best defence against the highly- infectious disease which has hit the UK earlier than usual this year.More people over the age of  have been vaccinated this year compared with , but less than one third of two and three-year-olds have had their jab.The number of patients booking doctors appointments with flu-like symptoms has increased by  per cent in the last week, according to the latest data from Public Health England.NHS National medical director Stephen Powis urged the  million Britons eligible for the free vaccination to get your jab now.Professor Powis said: We know that children are super spreaders of flu, particularly around the holiday season when theyre more likely to see elderly relatives.So our message is simple: the flu season is here, get your jab now.It might be the dference between a Christmas to remember, and one to forget.This winter, Public Health Englandrefreshed its Catch It, Bin It, Kill It campaign aiming to prevent the spread of the highly infectious disease with hygiene advice.PHE medical director Professor Yvonne Doyle also urged parents with children aged two and three to get them vaccinated as soon as possible.The health service in England has prepared for its largest ever flu protection drive to help keep people well and ease pressure on urgent care services over the colder months.Chief medical officer Chris Whitty said increasing numbers of people catching the infection puts pressure on hospital services, particularly as the disease worsens health conditions common among older people.Professor Whitty said: The winter flu season has started early in the UK and it is important that everyone who is eligible gets the flu jab from their GP or pharmacist.The vaccine is the best defence against flu whilst practising sensible hygiene can reduce the spread of flu.Professor Powis added: For older people and those with underlying health conditions, getting flu is particularly bad news because it can lead to really serious conditions like pneumonia and bronchitis, which can mean a y stay in hospital.People aged over , young children, pregnant women and those who have underlying medical conditions are particularly encouraged to book their flu jab, and get a nasal spray from a pharmacy.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gavin stacey mathew horne apologises laura kuenssberg disingenuous plopcarpet twitter
story: Horne has backtracked, saying he was caught up in the frenzy of the election when he attacked the political editor and called for her to resign.The TV star tweeted: I apologise to both @bbclaurak and the BBC for my comments on election night.I was caught up in the frenzy of the election and realised I used my public  and passion for politics in an incorrect way.I regret this  we should stand together.Merry Christmas one and all.Horne was reacting to the journalist’s coverage on BBC, including Labour’s losses in Nottinghamshire, where the actor grew up.In tweets now deleted, he wrote: “I really wish I loved myself as much as you Laura @bbclaurak”, and, “Let’s see...your ‘journalism’ knows no bounds. Resign, you disingenuous plopcarpet.”In other tweets reacting to the exit poll predicting a huge Conservative majority, Horne wrote: “Call me a coward, I’m off.I’m leaving this unfathomable country,” and he added, “the turkeys have voted for Christmas”.In a final tweet at .am, he added: “I appreciate my political tweeting this evening has been unpalatable for a lot of people... My stance: IDGAF [‘I don’t give a f***’].”The actor issued a grovelling apology saying he got caught up in the frenzy of the election.In response, Kuenssberg tweeted: Apology accepted - no one wins when we scream and shout rather than talk - maybe Twitter could move on from being Bitter in  - in meantime looking forward to Gavin and Stacey Christmas special once st week of new parly, last #Brexitcast of  and Brexit Storm  out the way.Political editor Kuenssberg, , has been subjected to a stream of online attacks, often from Corbyn followers.In  it was reported the abuse had become so bad that she required a bodyguard when she covered that year’s Labour conference.A BBC presenter, who asked not to be named, told The Mail on Sunday: “I think Laura is an outstanding journalist and possibly the hardest working person in our business.“She is also incredibly generous to those she works with and a total team player. The fact people are trying to get her fired – continually – speaks to the pathetic state of political discourse from a tiny cult.“Let’s not forget she needed a bodyguard at the Labour conference. An utter disgrace and a shambles.”BBC editorial guidelines prohibit employees from engaging in social media activity that brings the Corporation into disrepute.Horne has appeared in the BBC programmes Bad Education, The Catherine Tate Show and the  reboot of Are You Being Served  But he is not a direct employee and the guidelines may not apply to him.The tweets mark an embarrassment for the BBC, which is set to feature the much-anticipated revival of Gavin And Stacey on Christmas Day.

title: caroline flint blasts emily thornberry for calling voters stupid
story: Ms Thornberry said it was an “utter lie” to suggest she had laughed at Leave supporters after Ms Flint claimed she made the comment to a colleague.It came after Ms Flint said anti-Brexit frontbenchers like Keir Starmer, Hilary Benn, Yvette Cooper and Ms Thornberry were responsible for sacricing dozens of Labour seats in the election.The ex-MP represented the Leave-backing Don Valley from  until she was booted out by Tory candidate Nick Fletcher on Thursday.When pushed on whether Mr Starmer should replace Jeremy Corbyn, MsFlint told Sky’s Sophy Ridge: “Keir Starmer led us to a policy that didn’t listen to Labour leave voices that urged caution.“He led us down a path of a nd referendum and I’m afraid Emily Thornberry as well.“She said to one of my colleagues ‘I’m glad my constituents aren’t as stupid as yours’.Im sorry its unacceptable.She added: We shouldn’t for one minute think that a change of leader is going to create an election victory for us.”Ms Thornberry was widely criticised five years ago when she mocked a white van man for draping an England flag out of the window of his home.But today the Labour MP denied she made the comments about Leave voters and said Ms Flint was lying.She said: This is a total and utter lie. I have never said this to anyone, nor anything like it, and I hope needless to say, it is not something I would ever think”.It is believed that Ms Thornberry is getting legal advice over Ms Flints comments.Sources said the Islington South MP is very upset about the unacceptable allegation, MailOnline reports.Ms Flint told Ridge anyone in Labour who did not believe Mr Corbyn and Brexit were at fault for losing votes were in denial.She said that ardent Remainers in the party were at fault for losing the trust of voters outside of metropolitan areas.Ms Flint told Ridge: I do believe that in pursuit of Remain, they have contributed to sacricing  seats.“But don’t worry we’ve got Putney and we’ve got Canterbury, with all due respect to Labour MPs in those constituencies – I don’t think it was worth it.”Ms Flint said that the next leader of the party cant be Corbyn without a beard and doubted that any of the favourites - like Mr Starmer and Ms Thornberry - could deliver the votes Labour needs.Instead she suggested Lisa Nandy or Rebecca Long-Bailey should be the next boss.Ms Flint said: “I don’t believe anybody who have been the architects of our euro policy in the past few years are credible to be leader, they won’t win back these seats.I don’t believe there is any credibility for these people.“There was an underlying scepticism among my voters on whether Labour could deliver.“This is a terrible time for the Labour party and the Labour movement.”

Nandy, , will declare shortly she’s running, with Gtr Manchester mayor Andy Burnham and one-time deputy leadership contender Jon Cruddas already on her campaign team. I have known that Conservative MPs have feared Nandy for a while. When a majority of Labour MPs are female, it’s historically shameful that a party preaching equality has decided that for  years the best person for the top job was always a man. The next leader should be from their talented group of women. Nandy may be up against Angela Rayner, Rebecca Long-Bailey, Emily Thornberry and Jess Phillips in the race.

One party figure said: The real question is whether Angela and Beccyaposs friendship is strong enough to withhold the external pressure. A Corbyn loyalist described Ms Long-Bailey as the leftaposs only hope - but admitted they werenapost over-enthusiastic about Mr Burgon. Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said shadow business secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey could be a brilliant leader before praising shadow cabinet ministers Angela Rayner, Richard Burgon and Dawn Butler.  Another Labour source predicted the race will be a very crowded field, at least at first. Ms Nandy, who has campaigned for left-behind towns, today called for Labouraposs headquarters to move out of London in order to reconnect the party with voters outside of the capital. We should move our party conferences back to towns as well as cities, she added.She claimed it was undoubtedly true that Jeremy Corbyn is to blame for the devastating defeat after Labour won  seats in the general election , its worst showing since .

title: mirror readers say what labour
story: NewsMirror readers have their say on Labours failings - and what they should do nextBe it Brexit, Corbyn, anti-Semitism, or socialism, here Daily Mirror readers give their views on the key factors many feel lay behind the Tory victoryShareCommentsByFiona ParkerRhian Lubin:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsThe party’s ruling body is expected to meet on January  to agree how and when to replace Jeremy Corbyn - who provoked fury with comments on the election defeat"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSince Labour’s catastrophic defeat last week, political commentators have had their say about where the party went wrong. Now, it’s your turn. It seems Labour could have a new leader by the end of March so it may help them to listen to our readers about what the party now needs. The party’s ruling body is expected to meet on January  to agree how and when to replace Jeremy Corbyn - who provoked fury today with comments on the election defeat. Senior figures reacted with dismay and anger to his insistence that Labour “won the argument” - despite losing  seats at the general election . Below, Daily Mirror readers give their views on the key factors many feel lay behind the Tory victory - be it Brexit , Corbyn, anti-Semitism, or socialism, here. But also, most importantly for Labour’s future, what you think must happen now within the party. If Labour is to rise from the ashes, what next  Here are a selection of your views... Colin Dawson, Plymouth, Devon The scale of Labour’s defeat is staggering, especially as it is supposed to be the party that represents ordinary working class people.The ­movement was effectively betrayed by a large section of the working class, who, in turn, were let down by a deluded Labour leadership, ­ideologically stuck in the s. If Labour is even to survive, it must come into the st century and move towards the centre ground. Alan Baber, Bideford, Devon Jeremy Corbyn must resign now to allow a new leader time to bed in. Shame on the ­electorate to put their trust in a serial liar! Alex Marshal, via Facebook Corbyn should go now. We need a younger, stronger leader.The party needs to keep the same policies but get rid of the old guard and the right-wing back-stabbers. Jack Walker, Cornwall Letaposs hope Labour go back to their s centrist strategy and elect a younger, more open-minded ­well-rounded leader who can win the next election in a landslide. Nikki Read, Colchester, Essex  Labour failed because it lost touch with its grassroots supporters. I work at a GP’s surgery and was raised in a family believing in social justice yet I couldn’t connect to Corbyn. It’s time to have a woman leading. I’ve been impressed with Angela Ray­­­ner and Jess Phillips. Tony Howard, Salford, Greater Manchester Now the dust has settled we should appoint a new leader as soon as possible. Sir Keir Starmer must be in the forefront, followed by Jess Phillips.Hopefully, Johnson will dig a hole big enough for him to fall into – the NHS crisis might just be his downfall.   Mary Taylor, Fairburn, West Yorkshire Labour should have walked this election. However, they took no notice of an earlier vote on Brexit and people disliked the antiquated ideas of Corbyn and McDonnell. They promised too many things – andit sounds too good to be true, it usually is. Let’s hope Labour learn from this and choose a leader more in touch with the people’s wishes. David Carman, Ramsgate, Kent I thought that the Tories were there for the taking. Now I wish Corbyn would make way for someone like Keir Starmer or Andy Burnham.   Kieren Williams, London  This election hinged on two key points, the leaders and Brexit. Labour lost on both. Polls showed what the country thought of Corbyn, despite the merit of his manesto – whereas Johnson, a racist, misogynist fired twice for lying, was someone many could get behind. The other issue was Brexit.Johnson ­promised to end it. Labour’s policy of a new referendum made sense but meant more Brexit. Labour needs to focus on those it is supposed to represent once more. Victor Laidlow, St Leonards-on-Sea, East Sussex Labour has failed the working classes by not ditching Corbyn long ago.I voted to leave the EU but had reservations when the facts came out and I realised we had been lied to by Boris and Co. Corbyn should resign with immediate effect and the party must deal with anti-Semitism. Labour must work hard to rebuild trustit wants to win an election again. Gina Connor, West Yorkshire Itaposs time we had a decent candidate to lead this party back to glory. Nick Stevenson, Northampton People didn’t vote blue because they believed in Boris.They refused to vote Labour because they didn’t believe in Corbyn. Susan E Dykes, Otley, West Yorkshire I was very disappointed with the election result but not surprised. I said months ago that with Corbyn as Labour leader, we would lose. His unpopularity was a deciding factor but he was too arrogant to see this. While the manesto was ­admirable, it was totally unrealistic. What we want are promises that can be kept. Finally, Labour’s stance on Brexit went against democracy. James Edge, Dereham, Norfolk  Keeley-Jasmine Cavendish, South East London For the Conservatives to win seats such as Rother Valley and Newcastle-under-Lyme, which have been held by Labour for  years, sends the clearest message that British people have no time for the Marxist policies of the current leadership.   Stephen Laing, Stockton-on-Tees, Co Durham This is Labour’s worst result since  and two men are directly to blame – John McDonnell and Jeremy Corbyn.Insular, ­delusional, London-centric Marxists who have alienated core Labour supporters in my North East patch. Corbyn has yet to apologise to the  dedicated MPs who lost their seats, which shows his ego. Andrew Gardner, Chester I voted Labour all my le but not this time – and it was because of Brexit.If Keir Starmer becomes leader, I won’t vote Labour again. Stuart Jarvis, Oxford A Leopard never changes its spots and time will show you how this right-wing government will deal with our NHS, the elderly, education and homelessness. I believe Corbyn is a good man but did not have the charisma to be the leader of the Labour Party.Fortunately, we have many talented politicians who could replace Corbyn – Andy Burnham is one. We must never let this country become overrun with greed.We need to be a more caring society and only a Labour government can deliver this. Victor Rones, Backnell, Berkshire  As a loyal supporter, I wish Jeremy Corbyn and the Labour Party all the best. I think that Emily Thornberry or Sir Keir Starmer would make good leaders as they are outspoken and would stand up to Boris Johnson at the Despatch Box. I believe the party must now go towards the centre a little. The manesto was good but they put too much in there. It was overloaded with ideas and plans, and people were confused by it, whereas the Tory manesto was a flimsy document but had a simple message. I’m Jewish and I think Jeremy is a decent chap but, unfortunately, the anti-Semitism allegations and accusations of being a terrorist sympathiser stuck. Rory Brown, Brighton, East Sussex The only way the party can regain any credibility and support of patriotic, working class grassroots supporters is to rid itself of the pernicious and undemocratic influence of Momentum and its  brand of elitist student politics that has destroyed my once great party.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A new Tory MP has been accused of misleading the public after a Facebook post that described him as an NHS nurse was quietly edited. Ian Levy shot to prominence on Friday after winning former mining community Blyth Valley, Labour since , in the first big upset of election night. But he now faces questions over a post on his Facebook page dated November  which originally said: As an NHS nurse myself, I am immensely proud of the investment by our Conservative government. This post was edited  days later and now describes him as an NHS mental health nursing assistant. A local NHS worker told the Mirror that despite sounding similar, the two roles were very dferent as becoming a registered nurse takes several years and can carry the power to detain people under the Mental Health Act. Colleagues were angry that he would lie about being a nurse to win votes, the worker claimed. They said: Nursing has professional status and thus comes with a level of trust within society. I am not dismissive of the role that nursing assistants and support workers play - they do a superb job. But there is a huge dference between the two roles.Mr Levy does not appear on the register of nurses held by the Nursing and Midwery Council , and his local NHS trust told Nursing Times that he was employed as a healthcare assistant.Another comment that is still on his Facebook page claims: I have worked for  years as a mental health nurse with the NHS. And the Mirror was sent a screenshot of a reply to the original post, from a Facebook user which said Nursing assistant Ian, which appeared to have been deleted. Judith Ellis, a former interim chair at the NMC, told Nursing Times that Mr Levy had not technically broken any rules as he did not use the full protected title registered nurse.  She told Nursing Times: I think he has misledhe’s said that he’s a mental health nurse, but it’s not protected so the NMC can do nothing. That’s the game he’s played. “He’s changed it now to a healthcare assistant in mental health, so he’s obviously aware. “This is my concern, that it happens all the time. It’s dficult, because you don’t say ‘somebody midwived someone’ but you do say ‘nursed.’ It’s a tricky one. But by not [protecting the term] we undermine the profession. It’s not fair and it deceives the public.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA top Labour MP has accused the BBC of consciously playing a part in the partyaposs worst election defeat since . Andy McDonald descended into a furious clash with presenter Justin Webb as he appeared to allege a deliberate attempt to hurt Labour on the part of the state broadcaster. The Shadow Transport Secretary accepted we got this terribly wrong - but joined John McDonnell and Jeremy Corbyn in putting some blame on the media. And he went further by point the finger directly at the BBC. It comes as the Tories also wage war on the BBC over supposed bias aposagainst Brexitapos. Ministers are boycotting the Today programme and threatening to cut funding by £m by decriminalising non-payment of the licence fee. BBC Radio aposs Today programme presenter Justin Webb asked Mr McDonald about Labouraposs heavy losses and whether the partyaposs leader played a part in that. An Opinium poll last week found % of people who didnapost vote Labour cited the partyaposs leadership as their reason. But Mr McDonald said: Donapost get me started on the media, Justin. Iaposm very worried about our public service broadcaster. Are you saying that the BBC was in part responsible for Mr Corbynaposs loss  Webb asked. Mr McDonald replied: I am saying that they played a part. Iaposm really worried about the drt. Youaposve seen the catalogue of criticisms that weaposre making. Weaposve accepted that the print media are rained against us, but my goodness me. Iaposm going to look at us. Weaposre the important part here. We got this wrong, butthe BBC are going to hold themselves out as somehow having conducted themselves in an impartial manner, I think theyaposve really got to have a look in the mirror. Weaposve got a lot to say about this. Askedthe BBC consciously played a part, Mr McDonald replied: Consciously, yes. The BBC was hit by a string of rows over its coverage of the election campaign.  Its political editor was among journalists who tweeted unconfirmed reports that a Tory aide had been punched during a hospital visit. The reports later turned out to be  briefings from Tory sources - and branded a bare-faced lie by Labour. The elections watchdog also issued a warning after Laura Kuenssberg said postal vote s were grim for Labour. Viewing or sharing postal votes is banned under electoral law. The BBC said she had not broken the law. The BBC also said it accidentally used old footage of Boris Johnson laying a wreath at the Cenotaph, rather than this yearaposs clip in which he laid it upside down. A clip of a correspondent went viral after she said Boris Johnson deserves victory in what the BBC called a slip of the tongue. And the BBC accepted it made a mistake by editing a clip of Question Time to cut out audience laughter when Boris Johnson was asked about telling the truth. Meanwhile, the Tories were angry after interviewer Andrew Neil empty-chaired Boris Johnson - because he chickened out of an interview - with a devastating monologue on the Tory leaderaposs record and trustworthiness. Mr McDonald said: When you have a BBC presenter standing in front of a television camera saying aposand Boris Johnson is on his way to a richly-deserved victoryapos. Webb said: Oh, itaposs a slip of the tongue. Thataposs absolute madness, isnapost it  Mr McDonald said: How many slips of the tongue are we going to make until you accept it  I think itaposs a distraction, quite frankly. Because Iaposm accepting that we got this wrong ... you asked me about Jeremy Corbyn, Iaposll say to you quite clearly: he is a principled, decent man and heaposs vilied. I had in my constituency where posters were going up saying this man is effectively a paedophile, aposyou would not trust this man with your childrenapos. How much more do we need to do to demonise a good inidual  So, heaposs no longer going to be leader. The Brexit issue is going to be progressed, weaposre going to be out of the European Union on January  and we as the Labour Party have to galvanise around our core principles and make sure that we deliver for our people. Itaposs as simple as that. BBC director general Tony Hall emailed staff on Friday saying: In a frenetic campaign where we’ve produced hundreds of hours of output, of course we’ve made the odd mistake and we’ve held up our hands to them. Editors are making tough calls every minute of the day. But I don’t accept the view of those critics who jump on a handful of examples to suggest we’re somehow biased one way or the other. Election night presenter Huw Edwards waded in on Sunday, saying the toxic cynicism and accusations of biasare adding to the pressures on the entire team.

Jake Hague, , started aposfittingapos on the back seat of his girlfriendaposs car shortly after he took the powerful drug. An inquest at North Staffordshire Coroner’s Court heard how his girlfriend Louise Tivenan drove him to her house before calling an ambulance.His mother, Joanne Shaw, told the hearing at that she believed Jake may have survivedan ambulance had been called sooner, reports Stoke-on-TrentLive .Jake, of Meir, Staffordshire, met up with his girlfriend the day after his birthday last year. Brian, , who is originally from New Zealand, has been living in his three foot shelter in Cornwall since , when he opted to live the simpler le. He brands himself the parkaposs unofficial night watchman - keeping the grounds free of trouble and graffiti.Speaking to Cornwall Live , Brian said: When I first came down here in September  I had just done the South West footpath. I couldn’t decide where I wanted to go to be homeless.“It’s quite a big decision. There are lots of dferent places to choose from.  I decided to give here a go and now they can’t get rid of me. “I’m the unofficial night watchman.” Brian is well known in the area and often people will bring him food and stop by for a chat.The only time he has to move is when football matches are played - which in the current weather isnapost very often.He added: When they have a game I pack up all my stuff and put it behind the wall. Like a lot of pensioners, Brian will potter into town to pick up supplies a few times a week and locals often find him with his head buried in a book. However, his le today is a stark contrast to his younger years. The -year-old revealed he used to be an airline pilot and has been to places that most people can only dream of. “Hawaii and Fiji are like heaven on earth,” he says as he reminisces about old times. He says he worked for the UN in Vietnam and saw the true meaning of poverty while working in some of the poorest African nations in the s. When he failed his medical examination he lost his pilot’s licence and moved to London for a new start. “My career ended very abruptly so I started another one in London,” he says. He worked as a chef in London, Birmingham and Torquay but his le took a dramatic turn in his mid-s.   “That’s when the housing crisis arrived in the beginning of  and I said ‘sod it let’s try it the other way’. title: my mums pregnancy test before
story: NewsMy mums pregnancy test before I was born left me disabled for leGary McFarlane was born disabled and underwent more than  operations during his childhood. His mum was given Primodos, a hormone pregnancy test which was taken off the market in ShareCommentsByJenner HylandChiara Fiorillo:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsGary McFarlanewith mother Anne and little brother Stewart "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man believes he was born disabled because his mum took a hormone pregnancy test. Gary McFarlane, , has joined campaigners who believe the test was responsible for causing thousands of abnormalities in babies including heart defects, brain injuries and still births. Primodos was given to women from  until it was taken off the market in .By then, .million females in the UK had taken it, the Daily Record reports.When Gary was born in , his arms were permanently straight and he had only one finger and one thumb that worked on both hands. He also had club foot as well as dead muscle in both his upper arms and legs.Gary, of Drumchapel,  Glasgow , was transferred to London’s Great Ormond Street Hospital where he spent most of his childhood undergoing more than  painful operations in a bid to correct his arms, legs, hands and feet.He said: “The way I was born has affected me all my le – how I walk, how I carry things. I was told to get on with it and it was an act of God. “But now I feel that all I have been through could have been preventedmy mum had not been given Primodos.” The pregnancy test consisted of two pills that contained norethisterone and ethinylestradiol. It detected pregnancy by inducing menstruation in women who were not pregnant.  At the age of two, Gary underwent surgery where doctors broke his left arm and moved his chest muscle into his shoulder in an attempt to give him the ability to carry things with his arm, which was then fixed into a permanent position. He had always known his mother Anne, now , had taken Primodos when pregnant, but he decided to contact The Association for Children Damaged by Hormone Pregnancy Tests after seeing a TV documentary earlier this year. Gary, who now lives in Southport on Merseyside, said: “It had an incredible impact. To see that there were people out there like me who’ve lived a similar experience and don’t know why it happened. I showed my mum the documentary and she broke down.  “She had always told me growing up that she was given tablets while pregnant with me. “During her pregnancy, she felt something wasn’t right but the doctors told her it was her imagination. At that time,people didn’t question doctors. They took their word as gospel. “But the more I looked into it, the more I realised Primodos could be to blame. It’s heartbreaking because women wouldn’t have taken itthey’d been made aware of the risks.

title: size 22 mum sheds massive
story: NewsSize  mum sheds massive six stone after horrying Christmas party snapEmma Bass, , from Hertfordshire, thought she looked glamorous at the festive bash but was mortied when she saw the photosShareCommentsByHarriet WhiteheadJane LavenderAssistant Editor:,  DEC NewsEmma was horried when she saw this photo ather work Christmas do "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEmma Bass felt a million dollars when she put on a specially bought dress for a work Christmas night out. But when the then size  childrenaposs nanny saw photos of the night she was mortied and vowed to lose weight. Emma, from Hoddesdon, Hertfordshire, admits she has been a yoyo dieter all her le. The -year-old says she used to scoff double dinners and biscuits and her weight had reached stone lbs when the pictures were taken in . She said: I knew I was big, but the turning point came after seeing myself in a photo from a work Christmas do in December . I’d felt quite glamorous on that night. I liked the dress I’d bought, so it was quite a shock when I saw the picture and realised how big I was. It felt like every bit of me was bursting out of the dress.  And when she visited her GP for a review of her contraceptive Pill, Emma was referred to the slimming club WW. The mum-of-one has now shed a massive six stone and was a slim size  when she married partner, Russell Baas in July last year. Her wedding dress even needed to be taken in from a size  to a size  before her big day. Emma said: I was overweight at school and would get bullied. At home, food was always there. There would be a pudding with every meal. I did lose some weight when I was , but the bullies found something  to pick on, so I went back to my old ways. As an adult, I tried dferent diets, but never really stuck to anything, and eventually got to st lb and was wearing a size . When the photo that changed everything was taken ft ins Emma had a body mass index of . compared to the NHS recommended figure of between . to ., meaning she was obese.  Emma, who has a son Zac, eight, and a teenage stepson, said: Food had always been a massive comfort to me, so I had grown used to eating on my feelings and had just been getting bigger and bigger. I told myself I didn’t care what I looked like, but really I was feeling so rubbish about myself. My self-esteem was at rock bottom, so I didn’t feel like it mattered what I was eating. But her weight was taking its toll on her health and saw her struggling with the physical demands of her nannying job. She said:always had bad knees and my back always hurt. I had quite a physical job as a nanny and found getting the children in and out of the car quite hard. I never had any portion control and would eat a lot of carbs, like a big portion of lasagne and chips for tea. I would sometimes eat two dinners, eating my main meal at work then a bowl of cereal when I got home, or the other way round.  I’d sit with a friend and we’d think nothing of sharing a whole packet of biscuits between us. I went on dating apps but that was bad for my confidence. Iaposd look my best in the picture, but when dates meet me theyaposd realise Iaposm a bigger girl and that would be it. Iaposve got a history of depression, so looking after myself hasnapost always been important. I always foundI was having a bad patch I would turn to food for comfort and my healthy lestyle became more of a battle. In January , soon after seeing the shocking photo from her Christmas do, Emma had a routine appointment at her GP surgery and was referred to WW. She said: The WW system would give me control over my portion sizes. Nothing was off limits which really helped. My weight loss journey has been slow - it’s taken me three and a half years and a lot of hard work because I did it in small steps, rather than having a massive loss - but itaposs worked.  Slowly but surely, Emma, who was no longer with her sonaposs dad, started to win her battle of the bulge. She said: I’ve always been a plodder and it is hard to keep motivatedyou’re just losing the odd pound. Mine isn’t a typical story really. My weight came off very slowly and there were set backs, as I had some short relationships which had ended but it’s still signicant and I want people to know that losing weight is dferent for everyone, and not to give up. I set mini goals. I knew, for example, thatthe school holidays were coming up there would be constant picnics, so it became about maintaining my weight rather than losing it.I’d also post progress photos on Instagram to try and monitor how I was doing.Thein in Januaru, , Emma met Russell, , online. He proposed the following December at the ice rink at the Natural History Museum in London, spurred Emma on.  Emma said: The wedding was planned for that July, so for the next six months I had a massive incentive to motivate me. I started going to the gym and invested in a personal trainer, having previously done no exercise. I would go to the gym two or three times a week. I got a step tracker and started walking into work, becoming quite competitive about getting my steps in. I bought my wedding dress in January and it was a size , but I should have bought a size , as by the time of our wedding my body shape changed so much, because of the exercise. The alterations cost almost as much as the dress. I know a lot of brides buy a dress too small as motivation but I didn’t want that kind of pressure. If Iaposd fallen over and broken my leg and not been able to exercise I would never have lost that weight.Before the wedding, Emma enjoyed the fruits of her labour in the gym when she bought a size  playsuit for her hen night, which made her feel on top of the world. She said: It was really special going shopping for my hen weekend. It had always been a real challenge finding things that had fitted. I would hide away in baggy clothes, but this was completely dferent. It was an amazing feeling wearing the playsuit, then going on to walk down the aisle in my wedding dress, knowing I was looking the best I possibly could. It was something I did myself, nobody  did it for me. It was hard work, but it was a real achievement. Wearing her wedding dress was just one of the many memorable experiences that made Emmaaposs weight loss feel worthwhile. She said: I cried when I bought my first pair of size  shorts. And it was a monumental feeling dropping into the  stone bracket in March this year.

title: dark blues squad a bit short says mcpake ahead of transfer window
story: Manager James McPake is finalising plans for some winter additions to improve his struggling Dundee side as the January transfer window nears.In the summer, the Dens gaffer brought in a dozen new faces as the club aimed to recover quickly from Premiership relegation.He accepts that’s taken longer than everyone at the club had hoped but has vowed that will be the last window with wholesale changes to the Dark Blues playing squad.James said: “We’re speaking about how we’re going to recruit and what is needed in this window and the next to make us better.“We have been looking ahead at the January window since the summer. Everybody in this league would want to add quality to their squad.“Looking at the bench on Saturday at Arbroath, we are a bit short. If we get a couple of injuries then you are short but you are always looking to improve anyway.“I’ve said before, I don’t want to go back to chopping and changing  players or whatever every window. That has happened for a number of windows at this club and that has to stop.“That’s why we were so busy in the summer so we don’t have to keep doing that. It has taken a bit of time to get everything right since then.“We are looking where we are short and what we can add but it has to be quality not just to add numbers to bulk up the squad for the second half of the season.”Next up for the Dark Blues is a home clash with one of the form sides in the ision at the moment, Dunfermline.Since Dundee have taken just one point from their last , Stevie Crawford’s Pars have racked up three wins on the spin.“It shows you what can happen,” added James. “We’ve kind of switched. Dunfermline have started winning games and we’ve started losing them.“I met Stevie at a reserve game recently and we were talking about how quickly things can turn.“It shows you thatyou put a couple of results together you’re right back up there. They’re in the play-off places where we need to get back to.“It’s a big game on Saturday, we need to be really positive and take the game to them.”The Dens gaffer is wary of the threat posed by Dunfermline frontman Kevin Nisbet, who has scored  goals in his last seven matches for the Pars.But he says,his team can supply the Dundee strikers with the service Nisbet has enjoyed at East End Park then it’ll be the home attackers making the headlines.He said: “Nisbet is a player I like.“He was a threat in the first game of the season and we’ve obviously seen what he can do since then.“They get the ball into the box for him. The big thing is they’re creating the chances for him and he’s putting them away.“I believe we’ve got strikers who are every bit as good as anybody in the league – and they will score plenty of goals with the right service.Arbroath - Dundee: Dark Blues# winless run extends to four thanks to Bobby Linn#s curler" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp arbroath---dundee-dark-blues-winless-run-extends-to-four-thanks-to-bobby-linns-curler embed # secrettQXpZpu" data-secret"tQXpZpu" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"“With the strikers we’ve got in our team, we have to play to their strengths. It’s a great ball from Cammy Kerr and a really good finish.“Danny Johnson and Andrew Nelson are the same so,we can create chances, that will be a big plus for us because we know we have players to get us goals.”

title: dundee havent shaken off utd loss yet admits midfielder byrne
story: Shaun Byrne admits Dundee are still to shake off last month’s home derby defeat to rivals Dundee United as they look to end their four-game winless streak tomorrow.Since the - loss to the league leaders, the Dark Blues have managed just one point from the next nine available, losing to Inverness and QOS and drawing at Arbroath last weekend.Next up is a home clash with in-form Dunfermline tomorrow but Byrne is confident the Dens Park side can turn things around and rebuild the belief they had before the loss on November .He told the Tele: “The confidence has dropped massively.“You could see in the three games prior to the United game we were in a really good place and were confident.“I think that defeat hit us hard and we’ve not fully recovered as a team.“In the games after, we lost to Inverness and Queen of the South and you could see the confidence has been hit in the team after those results.“We need to dig in and work hard for each other – we are the only ones able to put it right.“Confidence is probably the biggest thing for a footballer. When you are full of confidence you try things you wouldn’t do when it’s low.“The only way it is going to come back is by picking up results and grafting in training.“Hopefully, we can turn things soon.”Dundee head back to Dens Park aiming to rebuild their relationship with the home faithful after some very disappointing displays.However, Byrne says the Pars are a perfect example of how quickly things can turn around after three straight wins has seen Stevie Crawford’s side shoot up the ision.Byrne said: “We’ve got to win the fans round but we have to do it for ourselves as well.“It’s down to us to get results. We know it hasn’t been good enough as a team and inidually, so we need to get results. Only those will get fans back onside.”He added: “You could see when we got our three wins in a row it pushed us right up the table and you can see that now with Dunfermline.“I think they were down in mid-table and now they are up in third. One result can change a lot in this league and we need that.“Dunfermline will come here confident after a few good results but we are at home and we need to use that advantage.“We had a decent home record up until the last few. We need to get wins here and make this a hard place to come.”Byrne began his career with Dunfermline in the old First Division before moving on to Livingston after three years.There are still one or two old faces around the club he remembers but the midfielder insists his only focus is on his own, and the team’s, performance.“It’s a club I know really well and they gave me a chance to play in the first team,” he added.“I have a lot of good memories there but it was a long time ago now. I want to concentrate on doing well for Dundee, though.“I know myself I’ve not been good enough. I’ve had some good games but I’ve not played well consistently enough week to week.“When we got those three wins in October I was starting to feel good. Inidually, I know I can be a lot better.“I’m not going to say I’m going to do this and that. I can only work as hard as possible and I’m sure it will come together again and I can get back to how I was playing last season and enjoying things again.”

title: mcpake set to welcome back key players for dunfermline clash
story: James McPake is set to welcome back some “key” players tomorrow against Dunfermline.The Dundee boss admits his side has been hit by absences during their bad run of form lately.With one of the league’s in-form teams checking in at Dens Park tomorrow, James is hopeful his side will get a boost from some added competition.A big miss has been left-back Jordan Marshall with a hamstring injury while striker Andrew Nelson may also be fit toto the squad.Centre-back Josh Meekings just fell short of fitness for the clash away to Arbroath last weekend and should be OK tomorrow.James said: “It was a really young bench at Arbroath. We are missing a few in key areas.“That’s football. You’re going to have times like this.”He added: “Marshall’s one has been a blow because he was set to be back in the squad earlier but broke down again. That was a sore one for us but we think he’s over the worst of it now.“We won’t be taking any chances with him when we get him back. The extra week will have helped him.“He hit the ground running and was consistently our best player from day one, I think.“He was everything we hoped he would be and probably a bit more.“I thought Sean Mackie did OK last Saturday, to be fair to him. He was one of our better performers in tough conditions.“But Marsh has been a miss. We’ve also missed the competition between them, you want the two of them fighting it out and keeping each other on their toes.“We’ll be happy to get Marshall back, hopefully, this weekend.”Central midfielder Jamie Ness has been ruled out for the weekend.

title: rgu graduations nicoles degree leads to promotion
story: Embarking on a degree at RGU allowed one student to balance her studies with full-time work.Mechanical and offshore engineering graduate, Nicole Cruden, , from Turrf, said: “I recently got promoted at work at the start of this year and I wouldn’t have been able to do thatit wasn’t for university.”The student who also completed an apprenticeship after school, worked as a full-time designer with Baker Hughes during her studies.She admits that balancing university and full-time work was dficult, but said the part-time course at RGU made it possible.Nicole commented: “The ability to study part-time whilst still working full time allowed me to further my education and complete my apprenticeship. If part-time study wasn’t available at RGU then I wouldn’t have been able to continue working.”She added: “It was challenging because I was working as well as studying. I tried to do as much as I could during the evenings, but obviously near exams it was hectic. title: letters to the editor november 1 2019
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,It is time for Remembrance again and many people will be wearing a red poppy in support of the allied servicemen and women who suffered during the last century.White poppies have been on sale since  to support and remember all victims of all wars, be they civilian or military and regardless of race or gender. Funds raised go towards the peace building work of the Peace Pledge Union, who are unashamedly against wars and the causes of wars.On Tuesday November  and Thursday November  we will be selling white poppies from the foyer of the Lochgilphead Co-op.Bob Dixon, MinardSir,I agree with the points made by Robert MacIntyre in last week#s edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser, when he says that the proposed education cuts are #madness#.This madness is being forced on councils by the SNP government and its Green Party allies at Holyrood, who for years have been voting for Scottish Government budgets which force councils to make cuts.Unless the SNP and the Greens change course and stop cutting the money they give to councils, this madness will continue.I hope that Mr MacIntyre, a former SNP councillor, will write to the leaders of the SNP and the Greens and demand they give councils enough money to stop these mad cuts.Councillor Alan Reid, Liberal Democrat candidate for Argyll and ButeDear AileenWe are responding to your recent consultation about the council budget.Whilst we are very sympathetic to the dficulties that all public bodies, including the Scottish Government, have faced as a result of a decade of austerity it is only fair to point out that this was imposed not by the Scottish Parliament, but by Westminster.The truth is that overall the Scottish Government has maintained the overall funding for local government, as a share of the overall budget, at around  per cent.Councils have, once again, the option of raising additional funds by increasing the council tax, something they have sought for a long while.The inidual share of the total funding allocated to councils is decided by COSLA, using a needs-based formula. Argyll and Bute Council will receive a total of £. million to fund their services in - which, taken alongside the council tax increase they have decided to implement, will give the council an additional £. million this year compared to last – a rise of . per cent.They will also receive their fair share of the extra funding that has already been announced during the current financial year including £ million for teacher’s pay and £. million for increased teacher’s pension contributions.The council could do a number of things to improve its own prospects.You and your administration could work hard to influence the COSLA formula which does not favour rural authorities with falling populations. The Scottish Government Cabinet Secretary for Finance has confirmed to us that he is always willing to consider suggestions, through COSLA, from inidual local authorities.You and your administration could be more imaginative in streamlining central management and devolving delivery and local decision-making closer to local people.You and your administration could maximise income whilst remembering that local businesses are the leblood of recovery. The recent massive hike in inspection charges for food products is an example of the wrong decision being likely to damage the economy rather than enhance it.You and your administration could maximise your assets by working with communities. The council has been slow to undertake any signicant asset transfer which could lead to useful and productive partnerships.You and your administration could be more responsive to, and careful with, communities. The waste of money and time on things like the abortive Traffic Regulating Order for Mull and Iona indicates where you are not using resource wisely and storing up dficulties for the future.You and your administration could ensure that any cuts do not fall on essential services needed for future success. The proposed reduction in educational support staff is an example of where a choice is being made that will not only be counterproductive in terms of our collective future and wellbeing, but will also lose the council local sympathy and support.And you and your administration could prepare to use the already agreed additional £ million for the rural growth deal – coming jointly from the Scottish and UK Governments # to make a long term dference in your performance by instituting a step change in the local economy.As your local constituency parliamentarians we are committed to ensuring the maximum resource comes from central government to Argyll and Bute.We are always happy to work alongside, and in support of, the council and we would be keen to meet to help you develop a detailed plan for the future of the area we are all elected to serve. But we must all be straight with local people and explain that responsibility for the dficulties that the council is experiencing do not all lie at the door of the Scottish Government, and therefore nor do all the possible solutions.Michael Russell MSP and Brendan O’Hara MP

title: negotiating the modern world
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsWhy is it so hard to negotiate the modern world That is the question asked by Dame Helen Mirren in the Radio Times. It is encouraging to know that beauty, fame and fortune do not insulate you from the insanities of everyday le.An infuriating attempt to find out the time of an audiology appointment at a national chain of chemist shops would provide material for a comedy show, as long as you were not the people concerned.A friend had arranged this appointment, but on the morning concerned had left behind her diary. Knowing the patient#s name, date of birth, address and audiologist#s name were not enough # post code was the key.  Her home post code did not work, the current one and a friend#s were rejected but inspiration struck and the previous hospital proved acceptable.Without best friend Google and someone to search for information, the day would have been ruined by the interpretation of data protection laws. The anomaly which made this ludicrous was that they were quite willing to cancel the appointment on the say so of the person they did not trust with the time.Have you had the frustration of doing a large supermarket shop early enough to beat the crowd, only to find you can#t add beer, evenit is labelled zero per cent alcohol  I fantasised about a situation where all the alcohol free wine, lager and even gin was made available, tempted people to sample, find jolly good and demand that the ied brands be available in pubs and eating places, instead of the ubiquitous coke.Alas, the alcohol trace in some of  these products mean that all fall foul of government policy. An excellent intention and the law of unintended consequences.

title: letters to the editor november 8 2019
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,In last week#s letters page you ran a version of the very long open letter addressed to me from the local SNP MP and MSP, a letter that they found the time to send to the press, but didn’t have the courtesy to send to me directly.On the council, all councillors work well together – particularly when addressing the major challenges the council faces. Last year the SNP councillors supported the administration’s budget, this year there were only slight dferences between the administration’s budget and the SNP’s one.It would be great to see our MP and MSP work with the council to make the case to the Scottish Government for more money for Argyll and Bute. COSLA has made a very clear request of the Scottish Government in terms of funding for local councils next year – three per cent plus inflation. The choices facing the council would be substantially dferentthis was delivered and of course it’s the Scottish Cabinet, including our MSP, who actually make the decisions.The fact is that over the past  years, the council has had to make savings of over £million. That means real hardship for many local people – many jobs lost, many services withdrawn. That is the sad reality.Like all councillors I#m sure, I would be happy to work with the local MP and MSP to make the case for more funding for Argyll and Bute.Councillor Aileen Morton, Argyll and Bute Council leaderSir,Regarding council leader Aileen Morton’s comments in the edition of the Advertiser dated October  # why should the public tolerate more cuts to their services year on yearthey are consistently paying their council tax and other taxes This seems unfair and should be challenged. Surely council leader Morton should be saying to the Scottish Government that the funding provided is not enough and we can’t make any more cuts.Instead of a reduced budget, the council should be asking for an increased budget to operate services when you consider all the cutbacks to their budget over the past few years.Perhapsthe situation was made clear to the Scottish Government by local councils that annual cuts to local authority services cannot be sustained, this situation will stop.It is unfair on council staff too, with threats of cutbacks having a negative effect on their own jobs through no fault of their own. Adding more work to an employee already struggling with their workload causes more stress which is not good for staff or their employer.Instead of accepting a reduced budget, please therefore can the budget be challenged and not accepted Peter Laing, LochgilpheadSir,Being non-funded, Mojo Festival of Original Music relies on my own initial outlay and the kindly volunteering of the team to help achieve at least a small bonus for all the hard working and talented acts who put on a really good night at the event.This year, even though we had more expenses, we had an even bigger attendance which meant we made roughly the same profit as last yearto share out, giving the bands £ each. Also the bands sold tickets along with their merchandise to give an extra £ approx to the cause. We had a total of  people in attendancewhich is our best ever turnout.The best part though was how much everyone enjoyed what was a night of some of the best original music Argyll has to offer # and you can#t put a price on that. Well done to all who were there and supported the whole event.Dan and crew, Mojo organisersSir,Among the many concerns caused by you-know-what is the very real fear that hospitals and high street pharmacies will run out of vital medical supplies which would normally arrive from factories in Malta, Hungary and Poland.So why are generic medicines not made in Lochgilphead, in Campbeltown and in Rothesay  After all, calcium supplement tablets are made in Galashiels by a Japanese brewery company.Glasgow Health Board built a brand new wee factory on the Western Infirmary Glasgow University campus  years to manufacture some but not all of their requirements. Not only did this save a great deal of money but the board  also earned considerable extra income by selling their products to other health boards, including Dumbarton and Argyll.All in all, the costs of building and equipping the Hillhead factory proved to be a very sound investment indeed.Duncan I Macdougall, TarbertSir,I write following last week#s open letter by SNP politicians Mike Russell and Brendan O#Hara in which they attempted to evade responsibility for the budget problems facing Argyll and Bute Council.These comments display extraordinary hypocrisy, revealing how out-of-touch these SNP politicians are with the realities of the challenges facing Argyll and Bute Council.The financial pressures on this council are a direct consequence of the repeated unfair financial settlements imposed on the council by the SNP government over the last  years.Brendan O#Hara should get on the phone to Nicola Sturgeon and demand a fair deal for Argyll and Bute instead of blaming everyone .Donald Cameron MSP, Highlands and Islands

title: science matters human impact on climate change then and now
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowHuman activity from the industrial revolution onwards is causing global warming which,not halted, will have catastrophic consequences.Now scientists suggest that human activity several centuries earlier also caused climate change*. But this had the opposite effect # cooling # resulting in the #Little Ice Age# between the th to th centuries.#In  Columbus sailed the ocean blue#, #discovering# the Americas and heralding unprecedented prosperity for Europeans. But for indigenous Americans it caused rapid, massive loss of le. This was mainly caused by the spread of lethal, Eurasian microbes carried by the Conquistadors. Literally thousands of infectious diseases, including smallpox, measles, scarlet fever, diphtheria and scarlet fever, killed millions of Americans who had no immunity or genetic resistance against them.#The Great Dying# saw the population plummet by  per cent, the final death toll being around  million. So began a chain of events which, scientists say, cooled the whole hemisphere.The Great Dying caused abandonment of approximately  million hectares of cultivated land – an area over twice size of UK. Natural reforestation of this land increased carbon uptake by plants, leading to a  consequent decline in atmospheric CO and finally a decrease in temperature – the Little Ice Age.  This theory is supported by coincident changes in local pollen deposits and by Antarctic ice-core records revealing trapped air bubbles from this time period with low CO levels.Any lessons for today Unfortunately, today#s problems are on a completely dferent scale. Reduction in CO by reforestation in the th century was comparable to just two years worth of fossil fuel emissions today.*A Koch et al. Quaternary Science Reviews -.
